review.title: Covered Clause Elimination
review.abstract: Generalizing the novel clause elimination procedures developed in [M. Heule, M. J\"arvisalo, and A. Biere. Clause elimination procedures for CNF formulas. In Proc. LPAR-17, volume 6397 of LNCS, pages 357-371. Springer, 2010.], we introduce explicit (CCE), hidden (HCCE), and asymmetric (ACCE) variants of a procedure that eliminates covered clauses from CNF formulas. We show that these procedures are more effective in reducing CNF formulas than the respective variants of blocked clause elimination, and may hence be interesting as new preprocessing/simplification techniques for SAT solving.

sections.heading: 3 Discussion and Conclusions
sections.text: Our current provisional implementation of CCE requires, on average, twice the calculation cost of BCE on the 2009 SAT Competition standard of application, which was set when applied up to a fixed point. This means that in practice, CCE can be done fairly quickly. In terms of the practical effectiveness of CCE, CCE (F) is roughly equal to BCE (F) in about half of the cases (the difference is less than 10 clauses). In the other half, however, the additional reduction is about 5% compared to BCE; in the best case, we observed a case where the additional reduction was up to 40%. As further work on this issue progresses, we will focus on continuing to investigate the effectiveness of CCE in practice, and also the possibilities of implementing HCCE and ACCE. In this context, it is important to note that even if a particular elimination technique is too costly for practical purposes to be carried out up to a fixed point, such a technique may only be of practical benefit for a long time.
